qas.question: Tamudic schools are known as what?
what are the colleges married men study in called?
Haredi and Chassidic communities are threatened by assimilation and intermarriage so they do not do what with non-orthodox populaions?
Haredi Jews do not share what with other jewish sects?
What resulted in the rise of heterogeneous enclaves?
Who refused to practice assimilation and intermarriage in enclaves?
What practice proved unsuccessful to the adherents of Orthodox Judaism?
Who estimate that less Jewish men are studying in Talmudic schools?

context: In practice, <b4_0>the <b6_0>emphasis on strictness<b6_0/><b4_0/> has resulted in the rise of "homogeneous enclaves" with other <b5_0>haredi Jews<b5_0/> that are less likely to be threatened by assimilation and intermarriage, or even to <a2_0>interact<a2_0/> with other Jews who do not share their <a3_0>doctrines<a3_0/>. Nevertheless, this strategy has proved successful and the number of adherents to Orthodox Judaism, especially Haredi and <b7_0>Chassidic communities<b7_0/>, has grown rapidly. Some <b8_0>scholars<b8_0/> estimate more Jewish men are studying in <a0_0>yeshivot<a0_0/> (Talmudic schools) and Kollelim (post-graduate <a1_0>Talmudical colleges<a1_0/> for married (male) students) than at any other time in history.[citation needed]
